attributes.title: Empathy and Alcohol Use
attributes.description: The goal of the current study is to advance knowledge about the association between empathy and alcohol use by examining these variables in a well-powered (n=1,080) sample of young adults using ecological momentary assessment (EMA) methodology. This study design allowed for daily reports of alcohol use, thereby eliminating recall bias, and assessment of empathy engagement (both affective and cognitive) multiple times per day, thus providing a measure of state-level empathy. As such, this study provides the first opportunity to disentangle the effects of trait versus state empathy in their associations with alcohol use. Multilevel modeling (Bryk & Raudenbush, 1998) will be used to model associations among individual differences in trait empathy and alcohol use across days at the between-person level, and associations among individual differences in state empathy and alcohol use at the within-person level.

q1.value: State and Trait Empathy and Alcohol Use; An Ecological Momentary Assessment Study

q2.value: Lakshmi Kumar, Kasey Creswell, Aidan G.C. Wright, Whitney R. Ringwald

q3.value:
The purpose of the study is to investigate the relationships between state and trait empathy and alcohol use in a large sample of young adults using ecological momentary assessment methodology.
Alcohol is one of the most widely consumed psychoactive substances in the world. According to the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, about 70% of people in the United States over the age of 18 reported drinking in the past year and about 50% reported drinking in the past month (NSDUH, 2018). Excessive alcohol use can increase the risk of health problems and is associated with adverse psychological and social consequences. In fact, excessive alcohol use is responsible for around 88,000 deaths each year, including 1 in 10 deaths among working age adults (CDC, 2019). 
Alcohol is best described as a social drug because it is most often consumed in social contexts such as bars, parties, and social gatherings (Fairbairn & Sayette, 2014; Hendriks et al., 2018). Alcohol consumption plays a particularly large role in young people’s social identity exploration, and expectancies of social facilitation are especially powerful in young adult drinkers (Rideout et al., 2012; Patrick et al., 2011). The importance of the social context of alcohol use is also apparent from research that demonstrates robust effects of peer influence, social norms, and social networks on young adult alcohol consumption (Bot et al., 2005; Maxwell et al., 2005; Urberg et al., 2003). Therefore, identifying relevant social factors in the etiology of alcohol use problems is particularly important and can better inform prevention strategies against risky drinking behavior (Creswell et al., 2012).
The present study will focus on empathy as it relates to alcohol use because of the critical role empathy plays in social relationships. Empathy is typically defined as the capacity to understand another’s perspective or mental state (cognitive empathy) and the capacity to respond with an appropriate emotion to another’s emotional state (affective empathy) (Hoffman, 1982; Riggio et al., 1989). The ability to empathize with others is vital for everyday social interactions and for the development and maintenance of long-term relationships (Ashington & Jenkins, 1995; de Waal, 2008; Goldstein & Winner, 2012). Empathy has been construed as both a between-person (trait level) and within-person (state level) construct (Graaff et al., 2015; Nezlek et al., 2001; Nezlek et al., 2007). Trait empathy can be thought of as a general tendency for a person to show empathy, whereas state empathy can be thought of as a person’s fluctuations in empathy in response to particular interpersonal interactions (Graaff et al., 2015; Nezlek et al., 2001) or features of the social context (Zaki, 2014). The motivated model of empathy suggests that people are either driven to employ empathy or to avoid it (Zaki, 2014). Positive affect, affiliation, and social desirability typically motivate people to approach empathy, whereas competition, material costs, and cognitive costs typically motivate people to avoid empathy (Cameron et al., 2019; Zaki, 2014). This theory suggests that empathy is an adaptive process, and that people are more or less motivated to empathize depending on particular characteristics of the social context. Thus, though people show individual differences in average empathy (trait empathy), they can also fluctuate and shift meaningfully in their empathy across situations (state empathy). Importantly, state and trait empathy have been shown to function mathematically independent of one other, with each explaining some of the variance in empathy (Nezlek et al., 2007).
Social processes play an instrumental role in the development of alcohol problems (Sher et al., 2005), and empathy may be a particularly important social construct when considering risk. Several cross-sectional studies have found deficits in empathy for clinical samples of alcohol dependent individuals. Compared with controls, adults with alcohol dependence exhibited impairments in recognizing facial expressions of positive and negative emotions (Kornreich et al., 2002; Kornreich et al., 2013; Maurage et al., 2011a) and showed impairments in theory of mind (i.e., the ability to attribute mental states to others) and trait empathy (Bosco et al., 2013; Dethier & Blairy, 2012; Erol et al., 2016; Martinotti et al., 2009; Mohagheghi et al., 2015; Thoma et al., 2013), with particular impairments in affective (versus cognitive) empathy (Gizewski et al., 2013; Maurage et al., 2011b).
A few cross-sectional studies have also examined links between low trait empathy and increased alcohol consumption and problems in non-clinical samples. In a sample of African American adolescents, low trait empathy was associated with lower drug refusal self-efficacy and greater past 30-day drug use, but analyses were not conducted separately for cognitive versus affective empathy (Nguyen et al., 2011). In Italian adolescents, deficits in affective (but not cognitive) empathy were associated with binge drinking (Laghi et al., 2019a) and, in the presence of high conformity, impaired theory of mind was associated with more binge drinking episodes (Laghi et al., 2019b). Further, in a sample of French adolescents, both cognitive and affective empathy were found to be associated with alcohol problems and binge drinking (Lannoy et al., 2020). Finally, low emotional intelligence (of which empathy is a facet; Salovey et al., 2004) has been linked to greater past week and past month alcohol consumption in American middle-school students and with more heavy episodic drinking and more alcohol problems in Australian adults (Schutte et al., 2010; Trinidad & Johnson, 2000). 
Taken together, results from both clinical and non-clinical samples suggest that deficits in trait empathy are associated with increased alcohol consumption and more alcohol-related problems. We are unaware of prior studies that examined the relationships between state empathy and alcohol use or problems, however. Research on related constructs highlights why this work might be important. For instance, fluctuating mood states, which are context dependent, have been shown to robustly influence the direction, intensity, and persistence of a wide range of human behaviors (Holzahauer et al., 2020; Gardner, 1985; Gendolla, 2000; Gendolla & Brinkmann, 2005). Additionally, meaningful within‐person variability in the Big Five personality traits has helped to explain important trait-content manifestations of behavior (Ching et al., 2014; Fleeson, 2007; Fleeson & Glallagher, 2009; Geukes et al., 2017).  In general, more research is needed to explore associations between empathy and alcohol use and, in particular, the extent to which trait (versus state) empathy and cognitive (versus affective) empathy is linked to alcohol use. 
The goal of the current study is to advance knowledge about the association between empathy and alcohol use by examining these variables in a well-powered (n=1,080) sample of young adults using ecological momentary assessment (EMA) methodology. This study design allowed us to collect daily reports of alcohol use, thereby eliminating recall bias, and to assess empathy engagement (both affective and cognitive) multiple times per day, thus providing a measure of state-level empathy. As such, this study provides the first opportunity to disentangle the effects of trait versus state empathy in their associations with alcohol use. Specifically, while prior studies have shown that individuals with low trait empathy report more alcohol involvement, the current study will allow us to determine whether empathy is implicated in the within-person process of alcohol use behavior (e.g., do individuals drink more alcohol on days that they report lower empathy?).

Study Aim
1. Determine whether individual differences in empathy are associated with individual differences in daily drinking behavior. 
2. Determine whether daily fluctuations in empathy are associated with daily fluctuations in alcohol use.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Individual differences in trait empathy are expected to be associated with individual differences in daily drinking. People with lower trait empathy are expected to report more drinking days and more alcohol drinks per day than people with higher trait empathy. 
Hypothesis 2: Daily fluctuations in empathy (state empathy) are expected to be associated with fluctuations in same day alcohol use.
Hypothesis 3: Associations between empathy and alcohol use are expected to be stronger for affective (versus cognitive) empathy.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Procedure
Sample 1 and Sample 2
In both samples, participants completed baseline questionnaires and a ten-day EMA protocol. Participation was entirely online without direct contact with study staff. Participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. Failure to show understanding the following day on a short comprehension quiz led to exclusion from further participation.
Baseline questionnaires included a demographic questionnaire, one question about alcohol use, and assessments related to psychological and interpersonal functioning and personality as part of a larger project. The EMA protocol began within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. Surveys were delivered on a randomly initiated schedule between 9 AM and 9 PM, with a minimum of 90 minutes between surveys. Push notifications on the MetricWire smartphone application alerted participants to answer each survey, which contained the three state-level empathy questions. Participants in the student sample (sample 1) received five surveys per day, while those in the community sample (sample 2) received seven surveys per day. At the end of each day, participants were asked three questions about their daily alcohol use.

Sample 3
Participants completed baseline questionnaires and a seven-day EMA protocol. Similar to above, participation was entirely online without direct contact with study staff. Participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. Failure to show understanding the following day on a short comprehension quiz led to exclusion from further participation.
Baseline questionnaires included a demographic questionnaire, one question about alcohol use, the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (Spreng et al., 2009), and assessments related to psychological and interpersonal functioning and personality as part of a larger project. The EMA protocol began within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. Participants were instructed to initiate surveys immediately after five interpersonal interactions and to record their state-level empathy on the three questions described above. At the beginning of each day, participants were asked about their daily alcohol use the day prior.

q11.value: Data collection for this study is complete but no data have been shared or analyzed at the time of preregistering this report.

question.value:
Three samples with nearly identical protocols were used for this study (see above). For the student samples, participants had to be English-speaking students, enrolled full time at the University of Pittsburgh, and over the age of 18. For the community sample, participants had to be between 18 and 40 years of age and users of a smartphone running iOS or Android software. To recruit a distinct community sample, individuals were not eligible if they were enrolled in a full-time undergraduate program. Participants in the student samples received course credit for their participation. Participants in the community sample who completed baseline questionnaires were entered into prize drawings for $75 Amazon gift cards. Following these questionnaires, participants could elect to participate in the EMA portion of the study. Participants who completed 90% or greater of the total surveys administered during the study period received $100 Amazon gift cards. Gift cards of prorated value were given to those who completed less than 90% of surveys. 
The baseline questionnaires were entered online, typically in a single setting. Following the baseline questionnaires, participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. A short comprehension quiz was given following the training to check for understanding. Failure to show adequate comprehension lead to exclusion from further participation.
EMA surveys were initiated within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. For Samples 1 and 2, surveys were delivered on a randomly initiated schedule between 9 AM and 9 PM, with a minimum of 90 minutes between surveys. Sample 1 received five surveys per day, and Sample 2 received seven surveys per day. At the end of each day, participants were asked about their daily alcohol use. A push notification alerted participants to answer each survey, which were then completed using the MetricWire smartphone application. For Sample 3, participants were instructed to record surveys for five interactions per day. At the beginning of each day, participants were asked about their alcohol use for the day prior.
Each EMA survey included items measuring affect, personality, and other variables of interest to the larger study. For Sample 1 and Sample 2, participants were asked if a social interaction had occurred since the last assessment. Interpersonal interactions were defined as real-time, direct conversations between the participant and one or more other individuals that lasted for at least five minutes. This could include in-person, voice, video, or text-based conversations. If an interaction had occurred, they were asked to complete the three state-level empathy questions. If participants indicated an interaction did not occur, they answered a different set of questions. Sample 3 filled out surveys containing empathy questions immediately after each of five interactions. They were instructed to initiate the survey immediately after an interaction occurred and were incentivized to complete five interactions per day because this was the only way they would receive course credit.

q13.value:
Samples
Sample 1
Undergraduate students (N=330) from an introductory psychology course at the University of Pittsburgh. 

Sample 2
Community members (N=342) recruited through posted flyers and online postings. Due to administrative oversight, the empathy items were not added until 13 days into the study. After excluding participants that did not receive these items the final sample size was 313.

Sample 3
Undergraduate students (N=437) from an introductory psychology course at the University of Pittsburgh.

question.value:
Measures
Demographics

Empathy
In all three samples, state-level empathy was measured throughout the day using two items corresponding to cognitive empathy (“I considered what the person I interacted with was thinking,” and “I considered what the person I interacted with was feeling”), and one item corresponding to affective empathy (“When the person I interacted with showed emotions, I felt their emotions inside of me”). Each item was rated on a slider scale from 0 (“Not at All”) to 100 (“Extremely”).

In Sample 3, trait empathy was measured at baseline using the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (Spreng et al., 2009), a short 16-item self-report measure of dispositional empathy that captures both cognitive and affective empathy.

Alcohol
Current alcohol use was measured at baseline with one item that was rated on a scale from 0 to 7 with the following response options: 0 (“I have never used alcohol”), 1 (“I used to drink but do not drink now”), 2 (“I drink socially but never to excess”), 3 (“I sometimes drink to the point of feeling “high””, 4 (“I usually drink moderately but will often drink more than I should”), 5 (“I often use alcohol to excess”), 6 (“I have had serious problems with my drinking”), and 7 (“I consider myself an alcoholic”).

Daily alcohol use was measured once each day using three items assessing whether participants drank alcohol in the past 24 hours (“yes”/”no”), what they drank (“beer”/”wine”/”liquor”/”other”), and how many standard drinks they consumed (open-ended response).

Given the hierarchical (i.e. days nested within people) nature of the data (daily average empathy and daily alcohol measures are nested within individuals), a multilevel model (Bryk & Raudenbush, 1998) will be used to model associations among individual differences in trait empathy and alcohol use across days at the between-person level, and associations among individual differences in state empathy and alcohol use at the within-person level. Multi-level structural equation modeling will help distinguish the effects of individual differences in empathy from the effects of daily level shifts from mean empathy. It will enable the evaluation of the extent to which alcohol use will associate with empathy in daily life, providing insight into empathy levels that are characteristic of greater alcohol use. All three samples will be pooled together for the main analyses (n=1,080).
Models will focus on associations between trait empathy and overall alcohol use and between state empathy and same-day alcohol use. Empathy measures will be included at Level 1 (person-centered) to capture the effects of within-person shifts from the mean, and at Level 2 (person means) to capture the effects of between-person differences. Two alcohol use measures will be examined as outcomes; a binary variable indicating whether subjects drank alcohol or not, and number of standard drinks subjects consumed. Mean differences between gender and sample types will be accounted for by including them as Level 2 predictors.

q24.value: In order to explore the direction of the associations, we will look at the associations between prior-day state empathy and next day alcohol use, as well as between prior day alcohol use and next day state empathy (data will be lagged by one day).

registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of the study is to investigate the relationships between state and trait empathy and alcohol use in a large sample of young adults using ecological momentary assessment methodology.
Alcohol is one of the most widely consumed psychoactive substances in the world. According to the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, about 70% of people in the United States over the age of 18 reported drinking in the past year and about 50% reported drinking in the past month (NSDUH, 2018). The motivated model of empathy suggests that people are either driven to employ empathy or to avoid it (Zaki, 2014). Positive affect, affiliation, and social desirability typically motivate people to approach empathy, whereas competition, material costs, and cognitive costs typically motivate people to avoid empathy (Cameron et al., 2019; Zaki, 2014). This theory suggests that empathy is an adaptive process, and that people are more or less motivated to empathize depending on particular characteristics of the social context. Thus, though people show individual differences in average empathy (trait empathy), they can also fluctuate and shift meaningfully in their empathy across situations (state empathy). Importantly, state and trait empathy have been shown to function mathematically independent of one other, with each explaining some of the variance in empathy (Nezlek et al., 2007).
Social processes play an instrumental role in the development of alcohol problems (Sher et al., 2005), and empathy may be a particularly important social construct when considering risk. Several cross-sectional studies have found deficits in empathy for clinical samples of alcohol dependent individuals. Compared with controls, adults with alcohol dependence exhibited impairments in recognizing facial expressions of positive and negative emotions (Kornreich et al., 2002; Kornreich et al., 2013; Maurage et al., 2011a) and showed impairments in theory of mind (i.e., the ability to attribute mental states to others) and trait empathy (Bosco et al., 2013; Dethier & Blairy, 2012; Erol et al., 2016; Martinotti et al., 2009; Mohagheghi et al., 2015; Thoma et al., 2013), with particular impairments in affective (versus cognitive) empathy (Gizewski et al., 2013; Maurage et al., 2011b).
A few cross-sectional studies have also examined links between low trait empathy and increased alcohol consumption and problems in non-clinical samples. In a sample of African American adolescents, low trait empathy was associated with lower drug refusal self-efficacy and greater past 30-day drug use, but analyses were not conducted separately for cognitive versus affective empathy (Nguyen et al., 2011). In Italian adolescents, deficits in affective (but not cognitive) empathy were associated with binge drinking (Laghi et al., 2019a) and, in the presence of high conformity, impaired theory of mind was associated with more binge drinking episodes (Laghi et al., 2019b). Further, in a sample of French adolescents, both cognitive and affective empathy were found to be associated with alcohol problems and binge drinking (Lannoy et al., 2020). Finally, low emotional intelligence (of which empathy is a facet; Salovey et al., 2004) has been linked to greater past week and past month alcohol consumption in American middle-school students and with more heavy episodic drinking and more alcohol problems in Australian adults (Schutte et al., 2010; Trinidad & Johnson, 2000). 
Taken together, results from both clinical and non-clinical samples suggest that deficits in trait empathy are associated with increased alcohol consumption and more alcohol-related problems. We are unaware of prior studies that examined the relationships between state empathy and alcohol use or problems, however. Research on related constructs highlights why this work might be important. For instance, fluctuating mood states, which are context dependent, have been shown to robustly influence the direction, intensity, and persistence of a wide range of human behaviors (Holzahauer et al., 2020; Gardner, 1985; Gendolla, 2000; Gendolla & Brinkmann, 2005). Additionally, meaningful within‐person variability in the Big Five personality traits has helped to explain important trait-content manifestations of behavior (Ching et al., 2014; Fleeson, 2007; Fleeson & Glallagher, 2009; Geukes et al., 2017).  In general, more research is needed to explore associations between empathy and alcohol use and, in particular, the extent to which trait (versus state) empathy and cognitive (versus affective) empathy is linked to alcohol use. 
The goal of the current study is to advance knowledge about the association between empathy and alcohol use by examining these variables in a well-powered (n=1,080) sample of young adults using ecological momentary assessment (EMA) methodology. This study design allowed us to collect daily reports of alcohol use, thereby eliminating recall bias, and to assess empathy engagement (both affective and cognitive) multiple times per day, thus providing a measure of state-level empathy. As such, this study provides the first opportunity to disentangle the effects of trait versus state empathy in their associations with alcohol use. Specifically, while prior studies have shown that individuals with low trait empathy report more alcohol involvement, the current study will allow us to determine whether empathy is implicated in the within-person process of alcohol use behavior (e.g., do individuals drink more alcohol on days that they report lower empathy?).

Study Aim
1. Determine whether individual differences in empathy are associated with individual differences in daily drinking behavior. 
2. Determine whether daily fluctuations in empathy are associated with daily fluctuations in alcohol use.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Individual differences in trait empathy are expected to be associated with individual differences in daily drinking. People with lower trait empathy are expected to report more drinking days and more alcohol drinks per day than people with higher trait empathy. 
Hypothesis 2: Daily fluctuations in empathy (state empathy) are expected to be associated with fluctuations in same day alcohol use.
Hypothesis 3: Associations between empathy and alcohol use are expected to be stronger for affective (versus cognitive) empathy.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

Samples
Sample 1
Undergraduate students (N=330) from an introductory psychology course at the University of Pittsburgh. 

Sample 2
Community members (N=342) recruited through posted flyers and online postings. Due to administrative oversight, the empathy items were not added until 13 days into the study. After excluding participants that did not receive these items the final sample size was 313.

Sample 3
Undergraduate students (N=437) from an introductory psychology course at the University of Pittsburgh.
registration_responses.q24: In order to explore the direction of the associations, we will look at the associations between prior-day state empathy and next day alcohol use, as well as between prior day alcohol use and next day state empathy (data will be lagged by one day).

registration_responses.q8.question:
Procedure
Sample 1 and Sample 2
In both samples, participants completed baseline questionnaires and a ten-day EMA protocol. Participation was entirely online without direct contact with study staff. Participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. Failure to show understanding the following day on a short comprehension quiz led to exclusion from further participation.
Baseline questionnaires included a demographic questionnaire, one question about alcohol use, and assessments related to psychological and interpersonal functioning and personality as part of a larger project. The EMA protocol began within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. Surveys were delivered on a randomly initiated schedule between 9 AM and 9 PM, with a minimum of 90 minutes between surveys. Push notifications on the MetricWire smartphone application alerted participants to answer each survey, which contained the three state-level empathy questions. Participants in the student sample (sample 1) received five surveys per day, while those in the community sample (sample 2) received seven surveys per day. At the end of each day, participants were asked three questions about their daily alcohol use.

Sample 3
Participants completed baseline questionnaires and a seven-day EMA protocol. Similar to above, participation was entirely online without direct contact with study staff. Participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. Failure to show understanding the following day on a short comprehension quiz led to exclusion from further participation.
Baseline questionnaires included a demographic questionnaire, one question about alcohol use, the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (Spreng et al., 2009), and assessments related to psychological and interpersonal functioning and personality as part of a larger project. The EMA protocol began within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. Participants were instructed to initiate surveys immediately after five interpersonal interactions and to record their state-level empathy on the three questions described above. At the beginning of each day, participants were asked about their daily alcohol use the day prior.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Three samples with nearly identical protocols were used for this study (see above). For the student samples, participants had to be English-speaking students, enrolled full time at the University of Pittsburgh, and over the age of 18. For the community sample, participants had to be between 18 and 40 years of age and users of a smartphone running iOS or Android software. To recruit a distinct community sample, individuals were not eligible if they were enrolled in a full-time undergraduate program. Participants in the student samples received course credit for their participation. Participants in the community sample who completed baseline questionnaires were entered into prize drawings for $75 Amazon gift cards. Following these questionnaires, participants could elect to participate in the EMA portion of the study. Participants who completed 90% or greater of the total surveys administered during the study period received $100 Amazon gift cards. Gift cards of prorated value were given to those who completed less than 90% of surveys. 
The baseline questionnaires were entered online, typically in a single setting. Following the baseline questionnaires, participants viewed a video training presentation explaining the EMA procedures and instructions for downloading the MetricWire smartphone application. A short comprehension quiz was given following the training to check for understanding. Failure to show adequate comprehension lead to exclusion from further participation.
EMA surveys were initiated within a few days of the baseline questionnaires. For Samples 1 and 2, surveys were delivered on a randomly initiated schedule between 9 AM and 9 PM, with a minimum of 90 minutes between surveys. Sample 1 received five surveys per day, and Sample 2 received seven surveys per day. At the end of each day, participants were asked about their daily alcohol use. A push notification alerted participants to answer each survey, which were then completed using the MetricWire smartphone application. For Sample 3, participants were instructed to record surveys for five interactions per day. At the beginning of each day, participants were asked about their alcohol use for the day prior.
Each EMA survey included items measuring affect, personality, and other variables of interest to the larger study. For Sample 1 and Sample 2, participants were asked if a social interaction had occurred since the last assessment. Interpersonal interactions were defined as real-time, direct conversations between the participant and one or more other individuals that lasted for at least five minutes. This could include in-person, voice, video, or text-based conversations. If an interaction had occurred, they were asked to complete the three state-level empathy questions. If participants indicated an interaction did not occur, they answered a different set of questions. Sample 3 filled out surveys containing empathy questions immediately after each of five interactions. They were instructed to initiate the survey immediately after an interaction occurred and were incentivized to complete five interactions per day because this was the only way they would receive course credit.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Measures
Demographics

Empathy
In all three samples, state-level empathy was measured throughout the day using two items corresponding to cognitive empathy (“I considered what the person I interacted with was thinking,” and “I considered what the person I interacted with was feeling”), and one item corresponding to affective empathy (“When the person I interacted with showed emotions, I felt their emotions inside of me”). Each item was rated on a slider scale from 0 (“Not at All”) to 100 (“Extremely”).

In Sample 3, trait empathy was measured at baseline using the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (Spreng et al., 2009), a short 16-item self-report measure of dispositional empathy that captures both cognitive and affective empathy.

Alcohol
Current alcohol use was measured at baseline with one item that was rated on a scale from 0 to 7 with the following response options: 0 (“I have never used alcohol”), 1 (“I used to drink but do not drink now”), 2 (“I drink socially but never to excess”), 3 (“I sometimes drink to the point of feeling “high””, 4 (“I usually drink moderately but will often drink more than I should”), 5 (“I often use alcohol to excess”), 6 (“I have had serious problems with my drinking”), and 7 (“I consider myself an alcoholic”).

Daily alcohol use was measured once each day using three items assessing whether participants drank alcohol in the past 24 hours (“yes”/”no”), what they drank (“beer”/”wine”/”liquor”/”other”), and how many standard drinks they consumed (open-ended response).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Given the hierarchical (i.e. days nested within people) nature of the data (daily average empathy and daily alcohol measures are nested within individuals), a multilevel model (Bryk & Raudenbush, 1998) will be used to model associations among individual differences in trait empathy and alcohol use across days at the between-person level, and associations among individual differences in state empathy and alcohol use at the within-person level. Multi-level structural equation modeling will help distinguish the effects of individual differences in empathy from the effects of daily level shifts from mean empathy. It will enable the evaluation of the extent to which alcohol use will associate with empathy in daily life, providing insight into empathy levels that are characteristic of greater alcohol use. All three samples will be pooled together for the main analyses (n=1,080).
Models will focus on associations between trait empathy and overall alcohol use and between state empathy and same-day alcohol use. Empathy measures will be included at Level 1 (person-centered) to capture the effects of within-person shifts from the mean, and at Level 2 (person means) to capture the effects of between-person differences. Two alcohol use measures will be examined as outcomes; a binary variable indicating whether subjects drank alcohol or not, and number of standard drinks subjects consumed. Mean differences between gender and sample types will be accounted for by including them as Level 2 predictors.

attributes.title: UBI Longitudinal Study
attributes.description: We are conducting a longitudinal, online study on support for cash-based policies over time, starting from the beginning of the economic impacts of the coronavirus outbreak. We aim specifically to assess how views of basic income policy (support for the policy) and its recipients (social distance to recipients and stigmatizing views) change over time in response to the GOP-led cash payments as part of the CARES Act, a stimulus package to provide relief during the COVID-19 outbreak. Additionally, we will test the impacts of an experimental intervention, which prompts participants to connect the experiences of financial insecurity of many Americans during the coronavirus to the experiences of financial insecurity that many American face in a typical year.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
All participants will view information on the CARES Act as follows: 

“The CARES Act is a historic stimulus package that was signed into law by President Trump a few days ago, on March 27, 2020. It is the largest emergency aid package that has been passed in the history of the United States. It allocates $2 trillion to help American households and the economy in the face of the coronavirus / COVID-19 outbreak.
Republican members of congress promoted direct cash payments to most Americans as part of the CARES Act. The CARES Act overall passed with near unanimous bipartisan support in Congress.     
In the coming weeks, Americans making below $75,000 as an individual (or $150,000 as a couple) are set to receive stimulus checks of $1,200 per person, with an additional $500 per child. Checks of smaller amounts will go to Americans making up to $99,000 as individuals (or $198,000 as a couple).”

Then, participants will be randomly assigned, via a Qualtrics randomizer, to receive an additional intervention related to financial insecurity (treatment) or no further information (control). 

Treatment condition: 
The financial insecurity prompts participants to connect the experiences of financial insecurity of many Americans during the coronavirus to the experiences of financial insecurity that many American face in a typical year (e.g. job losses or hours reduced, natural disasters). Then, we prompt participants to think about the following: “So, people are beginning to propose extending the CARES Act to provide monthly payments as basic income on an ongoing basis. This program would give people the flexibility and freedom to maintain financial independence in the face of disruptions. Giving people direct cash also means the government doesn't have to tell people what to do and allows individuals to make the best decisions for themselves in that moment, no matter what kind of financial disruption they face.” In response, participants are asked to describe how a basic income policy could be useful and/or promote important values in this country.

question2b.value:
ALL WAVES

For the longitudinal design, we measure at baseline (pre-intervention) and subsequent waves the following constructs:
 
1. Policy Support

Single-item policy support (1 item): “To what extent do you support or oppose a basic income policy that provides monthly cash payments to Americans?” (1 Oppose a great deal to 7 Support a great deal)

Dynamic norms on policy support (1 item): “Right now, to what extent do you think that support for a basic income policy will or will not increase in the United States in the future?” (1 Will not increase at all to 5=Will increase a great deal) 

Relative policy priority (1 item): “If the federal government were deciding how to spend $1 billion for public assistance programs, which programs do you think it should prioritize right now? Please rank the following forms of public assistance by what you think their priority should be in the box ("1" for top priority, "2" for second priority, "3" for third priority, "4" for fourth or last priority): job training program, basic income program, housing subsidy program, jobs guarantee program.

Zero-sum beliefs (composite of 2 items)
I would benefit from other Americans receiving basic income. (1=Strongly disagree to 7=Strongly agree)
A basic income policy would create better communities for all Americans. (1=Strongly disagree to 7=Strongly agree)

2. Views of basic income recipients (composite of 5 items relating to social distance towards and perceived characteristics of the recipient)
 [To be displayed after asking the participants to describe the typical recipient of receiving basic income, if it were implemented today]
How lazy or hardworking is this person? (1 Extremely lazy to 7 Extremely hardworking)
How irresponsible or responsible is this person? (1 Extremely irresponsible to 7 Extremely responsible)
How immoral or moral is this person? (1 Extremely immoral to 7 Extremely moral)
How much is this person not like you or like you? (1 Extremely not like me to 7 Extremely like me)
Please mark the picture that best describes how close you feel towards this person. (1=distant circles  to 7=overlapping circles)


3. Meritocracy beliefs (composite of 2 items) 
Most people who want to get ahead can make it if they’re willing to work hard.
Hard work and determination are no guarantee of success for most people.
*Meritocracy beliefs may not be measured at subsequent follow up waves.  



Wave 1 DV:

The initial experimental outcome for the Wave 1 survey is support for “extending the CARES Act to provide monthly payments as basic income on an ongoing basis.” 

Policy support (1 item)
To what extent do you support or oppose ongoing monthly cash payments to Americans? (1 Oppose a great deal to 7 Support a great deal)

question3b.value:
For the experimental effects, we will control for sociodemographics (e.g. age, gender, ethnicity, education level, income, day of survey within wave) that are not balanced across conditions. We will conduct robustness checks including these variables.  

We will conduct the analysis of the treatment effect with an interaction by political ideology (the extent to which participants identify as conservative on social and economic issues). This is an average score on two questions: “Please indicate your political identity on social issues (e.g., abortion, gun rights, gay rights). I am ____________ on social issues” and “indicate your political identity on economic issues (e.g., taxation, government spending). I am ____________ on economic issues” (7-point scale from “strongly liberal” to “strongly conservative”).

question10b.value: We will recruit approximately 2400 participants from Turk Prime, using the Qualification of “political views” to achieve a sample that more heavily weighs moderates and conservatives compared to liberals. In this baseline Wave 1 survey, we first assess baseline views on basic income policy, views of recipients of basic income policies, and meritocracy beliefs. question1a.value:
We are conducting a longitudinal, online study on support for cash-based policies over time, starting from the beginning of the economic impacts of the coronavirus outbreak. We aim specifically to assess how views of basic income policy (support for the policy) and its recipients (social distance to recipients and stigmatizing views) change over time in response to the GOP-led cash payments as part of the CARES Act, a stimulus package to provide relief during the COVID-19 outbreak. 
We will assess how these views shift over several months as developments in economic policies related to the coronavirus outbreak are enacted and implemented, with the first survey wave commencing March 31.  
 
Additionally, we will test the impacts of an experimental intervention. We will provide all respondents information on the CARES Act passed on March 27, 2020, specifically on the direct cash payments to most Americans of $1200 advanced by Republican members of congress. We will then randomize whether respondents receive an additional brief psychological message intended to highlight the need for financial security in America, by connecting the experiences of insecurity that many are facing now in response to COVID-19 with experiences of many Americans during a typical year. 
We hypothesize that this message will increase (a) support for an extension of the CARES Act to make cash payments ongoing  and (b) support for a basic income policy in subsequent waves.

question2a.value: We hypothesize that there will be an interaction by political views (a continuous measure of very liberal to very conservative), such that those who have more conservative beliefs will be more responsive to the intervention.

question3a.value: None are included as the control condition is not an active experimental condition.

question1c.value: For Wave 1, there will be only 1 confirmatory analysis ("To what extent do you support or oppose ongoing monthly cash payments to Americans?").

question3c.value: Treatment condition will be the IV. We will include political ideology as an interaction term.

question4c.value: We will control for any imbalanced covariates.

registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
All participants will view information on the CARES Act as follows: 

“The CARES Act is a historic stimulus package that was signed into law by President Trump a few days ago, on March 27, 2020. It is the largest emergency aid package that has been passed in the history of the United States. It allocates $2 trillion to help American households and the economy in the face of the coronavirus / COVID-19 outbreak.
Republican members of congress promoted direct cash payments to most Americans as part of the CARES Act. The CARES Act overall passed with near unanimous bipartisan support in Congress.     
In the coming weeks, Americans making below $75,000 as an individual (or $150,000 as a couple) are set to receive stimulus checks of $1,200 per person, with an additional $500 per child. Checks of smaller amounts will go to Americans making up to $99,000 as individuals (or $198,000 as a couple).”

Then, participants will be randomly assigned, via a Qualtrics randomizer, to receive an additional intervention related to financial insecurity (treatment) or no further information (control). 

Treatment condition: 
The financial insecurity prompts participants to connect the experiences of financial insecurity of many Americans during the coronavirus to the experiences of financial insecurity that many American face in a typical year (e.g. job losses or hours reduced, natural disasters). Then, we prompt participants to think about the following: “So, people are beginning to propose extending the CARES Act to provide monthly payments as basic income on an ongoing basis. This program would give people the flexibility and freedom to maintain financial independence in the face of disruptions. Giving people direct cash also means the government doesn't have to tell people what to do and allows individuals to make the best decisions for themselves in that moment, no matter what kind of financial disruption they face.” In response, participants are asked to describe how a basic income policy could be useful and/or promote important values in this country.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
ALL WAVES

For the longitudinal design, we measure at baseline (pre-intervention) and subsequent waves the following constructs:
 
1. Policy Support

Single-item policy support (1 item): “To what extent do you support or oppose a basic income policy that provides monthly cash payments to Americans?” (1 Oppose a great deal to 7 Support a great deal)

Dynamic norms on policy support (1 item): “Right now, to what extent do you think that support for a basic income policy will or will not increase in the United States in the future?” (1 Will not increase at all to 5=Will increase a great deal) 

Relative policy priority (1 item): “If the federal government were deciding how to spend $1 billion for public assistance programs, which programs do you think it should prioritize right now? Please rank the following forms of public assistance by what you think their priority should be in the box ("1" for top priority, "2" for second priority, "3" for third priority, "4" for fourth or last priority): job training program, basic income program, housing subsidy program, jobs guarantee program.

Zero-sum beliefs (composite of 2 items)
I would benefit from other Americans receiving basic income. (1=Strongly disagree to 7=Strongly agree)
A basic income policy would create better communities for all Americans. (1=Strongly disagree to 7=Strongly agree)

2. Views of basic income recipients (composite of 5 items relating to social distance towards and perceived characteristics of the recipient)
 [To be displayed after asking the participants to describe the typical recipient of receiving basic income, if it were implemented today]
How lazy or hardworking is this person? (1 Extremely lazy to 7 Extremely hardworking)
How irresponsible or responsible is this person? (1 Extremely irresponsible to 7 Extremely responsible)
How immoral or moral is this person? (1 Extremely immoral to 7 Extremely moral)
How much is this person not like you or like you? (1 Extremely not like me to 7 Extremely like me)
Please mark the picture that best describes how close you feel towards this person. (1=distant circles  to 7=overlapping circles)


3. Meritocracy beliefs (composite of 2 items) 
Most people who want to get ahead can make it if they’re willing to work hard.
Hard work and determination are no guarantee of success for most people.
*Meritocracy beliefs may not be measured at subsequent follow up waves.  



Wave 1 DV:

The initial experimental outcome for the Wave 1 survey is support for “extending the CARES Act to provide monthly payments as basic income on an ongoing basis.” 

Policy support (1 item)
To what extent do you support or oppose ongoing monthly cash payments to Americans? (1 Oppose a great deal to 7 Support a great deal)

We will conduct the analysis of the treatment effect with an interaction by political ideology (the extent to which participants identify as conservative on social and economic issues). This is an average score on two questions: “Please indicate your political identity on social issues (e.g., abortion, gun rights, gay rights). I am ____________ on social issues” and “indicate your political identity on economic issues (e.g., taxation, government spending). attributes.title: Left atrial parameters in cryptogenic stroke or embolic stroke of undetermined source (ESUS): a scoping review
attributes.description: This scoping review aims to survey and summarise the current evidence for various left atrial markers as predictors of recurrent ischemic stroke or occult atrial fibrillation detection. This may inform future research and clinical practice of selecting ESUS or cryptogenic stroke patients at high risk of cardiac embolism for anticoagulation rather than antiplatelet therapy.

q2.value: This scoping review aims to survey and summarise the current evidence for various left atrial markers as predictors of recurrent ischemic stroke or occult atrial fibrillation detection on echocardiography, CT and cardiac MRI.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The current scoping review is performed in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analysis extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) guidelines, and the protocol is determined a priori12. The methodology is developed according to the framework proposed by Levac et al. in Implementation Science13.

Stage 1: Identifying the research question
The research questions identified from the medical team are defined as:
•	In ESUS or cryptogenic stroke, are left atrial markers a robust predictor of recurrent ischemic stroke, occult atrial fibrillation detection or benefit with anticoagulation compared to antiplatelets?
•	Which left atrial markers identified are the best predictors of ESUS or cryptogenic stroke patients at high risk of cardiac embolism who may benefit from anticoagulation?
•	Which imaging modalities are suitable for measuring left atrial markers in ESUS or cryptogenic stroke, balancing the risk and benefits to such investigations?

Stage 2: Identifying relevant studies
The databases MEDLINE, Embase, Scopus, Web of Science, CENTRAL, OpenGrey, ClinicalTrials.gov are searched. Additional studies are identified from scanning of reference lists of included articles. There are no limitations on publication date, publication type, study type and language. Search strategies are evaluated using the Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies guidelines14, and defined in appendix 1.

Stage 3: Study selection
The inclusion criteria for this review include (1) any study on left atrial measurements or parameters (2) on clinical cardiac imaging including but not limited to echocardiography, CT and CMR, and (3) in human subjects who had a diagnosis of ESUS or cryptogenic stroke. Animal and in vitro studies, and studies where data cannot be reliably extracted, are excluded. There are no limitations on language of publication and type of study or publication. Two independent researchers will screen all identified titles and abstracts, and consensus is reached by discussion in cases of controversy. Full texts are reviewed after screening of abstracts by two researchers independently for inclusion into the review. In cases where full texts cannot be accessed or missing data is identified, the corresponding author is contacted for access or clarification.

Stage 4: Charting the data
Data will be extracted onto a standardized form by two independent reviewers and contradictions are resolved through discussion. This include publication information such as author, year and country, study population and study size, study design, echocardiography type, aims of the study including intervention and comparisons, outcomes measured and duration of follow-up. Safety information will also be collected. 

Stage 5: Collating, summarizing, and reporting the results
Quality assessments for all included studies will be performed according to validated protocols, for example the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool for randomised controlled trials15, the Newcastle/Ottawa scale for case series, cohort studies and case-control studies16, and the AMSTER Tool for systematic reviews17. Results are summarised qualitatively and in table of results. Quantitative outcomes analysed include left atrial parameters and association with prespecified clinical outcomes (recurrent ischemic stroke, occult atrial fibrillation detection and benefit from anticoagulation), safety outcomes regarding imaging and anticoagulation intervention.

attributes.title: Moral Growth Mindset is Associated with Change in Voluntary Service Engagement
attributes.description: Incremental implicit theories are associated with a belief regarding it is possible to improve one’s intelligence or ability through efforts. Previous studies have demonstrated that incremental implicit theories contributed to better academic achievement and positive youth development. Our study aimed to examine whether incremental implicit theories of morality significantly influenced change in students’ engagement in voluntary service activities. In our study, 54 Korean college students for Study 1 and 180 Korean 8th graders for Study 2 were recruited to conduct two two-wave studies. We surveyed participants’ implicit theories of morality and participation in voluntary service activities. The effect of implicit theories of morality on change in service engagement was analyzed through regression analysis. In Study 1, the moral growth mindset significantly moderated longitudinal change in service engagement. In Study 2, the moral growth mindset significantly influenced engagement in art-related activities, while it significantly moderated change in engagement in youth-related activities.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: This was mistakenly registered with the incorrect README description and outdated data files.

attributes.title: An exploration of autistic students' schooling experience.
attributes.description: This project aims to explore factors involved in academic outcomes for autistic students. The project will analyse data from two UK longitudinal twin studies (The Twins Early Development Study and the Social Relationships Study), and forms part of a PhD.

q1.value: Victoria Louise Milner, Francesca Happé, Emma Colvert

q2.value:
Below is a list of hypotheses to be tested using the Twin Early Development Study (TEDS) and the Social Relationships Study (SRStudy) data for the SRStudy sample:

1.	Within the SRS sample, autistic diagnosis will have a negative impact on academic attainment over and above IQ and family SES.

2.	The relationship between autism diagnosis and academic attainment will be mediated by mental health (SDQ scores).

3.	In discordant twin pairs, the autistic twin will have poorer academic attainment in comparison to the non-autistic twin (even adjusting for IQ), and this disparity will maintain when type of school placement is taken into account.

4.	Across the whole SRS sample, including comparison twins, autistic trait scores will predict academic attainment (negatively for arts subjects, positively for maths and science), regardless of diagnostic status (and controlling for IQ).

5.	Autistic twins will have different trajectories of school type (e.g. specialist, mainstream, and number of school changes) over time compared to non-autistic twins.

6.	Attitudes towards education will vary as a function of autism diagnostic status, school placement and number of schools attended.

7.	There will be an uneven profile in exam performance between groups; in the autistic group there will be greater within-individual variance in exam performance .

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The data used in this study are from the Social Relationships Study (SRStudy) which is a sub-study of the Twins Early Development Study (TEDS). TEDS is a longitudinal study that has followed twins born in England and Wales in 1994-1996 throughout their lives. SRStudy, which focuses on twins with high autistic traits/autism, is also longitudinal in design having collected data at three timepoints: ages 12-14 years, age 18 years and age 21-25 years.

The current study uses a two-participant group design: twins diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and non-ASD twins. Self-report and parent-report measures are included in the current study for all participants. 

For hypothesis 3, where there are discordant twin pairs, within twin pair analyses will be carried out, with non-ASD co-twins in comparison to ASD twins to control for SES and other confounding within-family variables. Between-group analyses will be carried out for all hypotheses.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The combination of data that will be analysed for this project has not previously been examined within the SRStudy. The researchers have observed the raw data for each variable individually, with no analysis of patterns or summary statistics. Furthermore, the additional new data requested from  TEDS, have not previously been seen by the researchers.

question.value:
We will be analysing data already collected by the SRStudy and/or TEDS.
All twins born in England and Wales between 1994 – 1996 were invited to take part in the TEDS project. Twin pairs where one or both twins were identified as having high levels of autistic traits, or a confirmed diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder, were invited to take part in the SRStudy. A sample of TEDS twins who scored low on autistic trait measures were invited to take part as a comparison group. Participants were offered vouchers (£5-£15) and prize draws for participation at different stages of the SRStudy (in person home visits at 12-14 years, postal measures at 18 years, in person home visits at 21-25 years). All twins included in the SRStudy will be involved in analysis for this project.

q11.value: The sample consists of 614 twins who have been involved in at least one stage of the SRStudy.

q12.value: The sample consists of any twin who has completed at least one stage of the SRStudy data collection and therefore has data related to academic attainment and autistic traits.

question.value: N/A

·	Demographic information (SES, gender, sex, zygosity)
·	Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ)
·	Childhood Autism Spectrum Test (CAST)
·	GCSE or equivalent results (by subject)
·	A-level or equivalent results (by subject)
·	School type (mainstream, specialist, specialist unit) when taking GCSEs
·	Types of schools (mainstream, specialist, specialist unit) attended throughout their lives (as recorded in the Autism Diagnostic Interview – Revised (ADI-R)).
·	Number of schools attended throughout their lives (as recorded in the ADI-R)
·	Parental attitudes to education
·	Academic Self-Concept
·	School Engagement
·	Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS) algorithm scores
·	Wechsler’s Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence (WASI) full scale IQ score
·	Self/Parent reported psychological health diagnoses checklist (e.g. autism)

Information about the informant and the stage at which these variables were collected is given in the attached document.

For the SDQ, standard domain scores will be computed for the following domains: prosocial, peer, hyperactivity, emotional and conduct. 

For the ADOS, calibrated severity scores will be calculated to allow for comparison across modules. 

For the WASI, standardised scores will be computed for all appropriate subdomains. 

Where appropriate, standard cut off scores will be used for all variables.

For exam results (GCSE and A-level), a sum total of all passes for grades A* - C and for A*-G will be computed. 

A sum of the total number of schools attended for each participant will be computed.

The following analyses assume normality of data. If the data are not normally distributed, the appropriate non-parametric tests will be conducted.

Descriptive statistics will identify any significant differences between autistic twins compared to their non-autistic co-twins and comparison groups for a range of factors including number of schools attended, type of schools attended, support received in school and academic attainment. T-test analyses will be conducted to explore group comparisons.

For hypothesis 1, multiple regression analyses will be run to predict total public exam passes from autism severity scores (e.g., ADOS calibrated severity scores, CAST scores at age 8 for the comparison group), IQ, sex and maternal education. Additionally, for hypothesis 1 a one-way ANCOVA will be conducted with diagnostic status as the IV and number of exam passes as the DV, adding IQ and SES as covariates.

For hypothesis 2, multiple regression analyses will be run to predict total public exam passes from autism severity scores (e.g., ADOS calibrated severity scores, CAST scores at age 8 for the comparison group) and SDQ emotional, conduct, peer, prosocial and hyperactivity mean domain scores for each participant group. Additionally, for hypothesis 2 a one-way ANCOVA will be run with diagnostic status as the IV and number of exam passes as the DV, IQ, adding SES and SDQ scores as covariates.

For hypothesis 3, an ANCOVA will be conducted with diagnostic status as the IV and number of exam passes as the DV. IQ and type of school will be added as covariates. 

For hypothesis 4, multiple regression analyses will be run to predict total public exam passes, and passes for science versus arts subjects, from autism severity scores (e.g., CAST scores and IQ. 

For hypothesis 5 descriptive data will be explored to identify the number and type of schools attended by autistic and non-autistic students. ANCOVA analyses will be conducted to see if there is a difference in the number of schools attended by each group, with IQ added as a covariate. A Chi-square analysis will be conducted to explore numbers attending which school types. 

For hypothesis 6 a multiple regression analysis will be run to predict autistic diagnostic status, school placement and number of schools attended from parental attitudes to education. 

For hypothesis 7 the patterns of the data will be examined using descriptive data and figures to visualise the patterns. Three participant groups will be created depending on exam scores by subject: participants who score similarly between science/maths and arts subjects, participants who perform better on arts subjects, and participants who perform better on science/maths subjects. Exam performance will be scored as “better” if the grade is two or more points different (e.g. C is two grade points from A). Group differences will then be explored using an ANVOCA with new exam pattern group as the IV and autistic traits (CAST score) as the DV, IQ will be included as a covariate. Chi-square analysis will be conducted to explore autism diagnostic status between groups. A dimensional approach to difference in exam scores will also be adopted. A sum of grade differences between pairs of arts-science subjects will be generated, for example if a participant’s results were English Lit A, English Lang B, History B, Science B, Maths C, and Computer Science C, a discrepancy score of 3 would be generated (one point between each pair, ordering within arts and science best to worst). Correlational analysis will then be conducted to see if there is a relationship between discrepancy scores and autistic traits. 

For all ANOVA/ANCOVA analyses, post-hoc Tukey tests will be conducted.

Bonferroni correction will be used for analyses with multiple conditions.  Effect sizes will be calculated and reported wherever possible.

Exploratory correlations will be run between autism trait measures (e.g. CAST at 8), number and type of schools and academic self-concept and school engagement.

registration_responses.q2:
Below is a list of hypotheses to be tested using the Twin Early Development Study (TEDS) and the Social Relationships Study (SRStudy) data for the SRStudy sample:

1.	Within the SRS sample, autistic diagnosis will have a negative impact on academic attainment over and above IQ and family SES.

2.	The relationship between autism diagnosis and academic attainment will be mediated by mental health (SDQ scores).

3.	In discordant twin pairs, the autistic twin will have poorer academic attainment in comparison to the non-autistic twin (even adjusting for IQ), and this disparity will maintain when type of school placement is taken into account.

4.	Across the whole SRS sample, including comparison twins, autistic trait scores will predict academic attainment (negatively for arts subjects, positively for maths and science), regardless of diagnostic status (and controlling for IQ).

5.	Autistic twins will have different trajectories of school type (e.g. specialist, mainstream, and number of school changes) over time compared to non-autistic twins.

6.	Attitudes towards education will vary as a function of autism diagnostic status, school placement and number of schools attended.

7.	There will be an uneven profile in exam performance between groups; in the autistic group there will be greater within-individual variance in exam performance .

registration_responses.q6.question:
The data used in this study are from the Social Relationships Study (SRStudy) which is a sub-study of the Twins Early Development Study (TEDS). TEDS is a longitudinal study that has followed twins born in England and Wales in 1994-1996 throughout their lives. SRStudy, which focuses on twins with high autistic traits/autism, is also longitudinal in design having collected data at three timepoints: ages 12-14 years, age 18 years and age 21-25 years.

The current study uses a two-participant group design: twins diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and non-ASD twins. Self-report and parent-report measures are included in the current study for all participants. 

For hypothesis 3, where there are discordant twin pairs, within twin pair analyses will be carried out, with non-ASD co-twins in comparison to ASD twins to control for SES and other confounding within-family variables. Between-group analyses will be carried out for all hypotheses.
registration_responses.q10.question:
We will be analysing data already collected by the SRStudy and/or TEDS.
All twins born in England and Wales between 1994 – 1996 were invited to take part in the TEDS project. Twin pairs where one or both twins were identified as having high levels of autistic traits, or a confirmed diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder, were invited to take part in the SRStudy. A sample of TEDS twins who scored low on autistic trait measures were invited to take part as a comparison group. Participants were offered vouchers (£5-£15) and prize draws for participation at different stages of the SRStudy (in person home visits at 12-14 years, postal measures at 18 years, in person home visits at 21-25 years). All twins included in the SRStudy will be involved in analysis for this project.

attributes.title: Helping or Harming? The Effect of Trigger Warnings on Individuals with Trauma Histories
attributes.description: Trigger warnings alert trauma survivors about potentially disturbing forthcoming content. However, empirical studies on trigger warnings suggest that they are functionally inert or cause small adverse side effects. We conducted a preregistered replication and extension of a previous experiment. Trauma survivors (n = 451) were randomly assigned to either receive or not receive trigger warnings prior to reading passages from world literature. We found no evidence that trigger warnings were helpful for trauma survivors, for those who self-reported a PTSD diagnosis, or for those who qualified for probable PTSD, even when survivors' trauma matched the passages' content. We found substantial evidence that trigger warnings countertherapeutically reinforce survivors' view of their trauma as central to their identity. Regarding replication hypotheses, the evidence was either ambiguous or substantially favored the hypothesis that trigger warnings have no effect. In summary, we find that trigger warnings are not helpful for trauma survivors.

attributes.title: Efficacy of ultrasonic activation in removing intracanal debris from mature permanent teeth a systematic review
attributes.description: The objective of this study is to compare by means of Micro-CT passive ultrasonic irrigation to non-activated irrigation protocol, regarding their respective abilities to reduce hard-tissue debris inside the root canals.

q1.value: Ana Flavia Almeida Barbosa, Emmanuel João Nogueira Leal Silva, Carolina Oliveira de Lima, Tatiana Fidalgo

q2.value:
H0- Passive ultrasonic irrigation and non-activated irrigation present the same ability to reduce hard-tissue debris inside the root canals.
H1-  Passive ultrasonic irrigation and non-activated irrigation present differences regarding their ability to reduce hard-tissue debris inside the root canals.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will be performed as a systematic review, an extensive research will be conducted across relevant electronic databases to identify and analyze all published studies that match the inclusion criteria. The goal is to analyze and compare the different results obtained by in-vitro studies that used Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation (PUI) and non-activated irrigation protocol with regards to their respective abilities to reduce hard-tissue debris within the root canals of human teeth following endodontic instrumentation based on Micro-CT analysis.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The search process will be performed independently by the two authors (A.F.A.B. and C.O.L.) The electronic databases PubMed, Scopus, Web of Science, BVS (Lilacs and BBO), Cochrane and Embase will be searched for articles published until april, 2020, without language or year restrictions. The electronic search strategy will be developed using most cited descriptors in previous publication on this theme, combining Medical Subject Heading terms (MeSH) and text word (tw). For each database, the following terms wil be combined: “Ultrasonic irrigation”, “Ultrasonic activation”, “Ultrasonic therapy”, “Ultrasonics”, “Ultrasonic*”, “Debris”, “Hard tissue debris” and “Smear layer”. The Boolean operators “AND” and “OR” will be applied to combine the terms and create the search strategy

question.value:
For in vitro studies, a quality assessment used in previous systematic reviews will be adopted with adaptations (Rosa et al. 2015; Sarkis-Onofre et al. 2014; Silva et al. 2018). For the qualitative assessment of the included studies, the following parameters will be considered: (1) Sample size calculation, (2) Samples with similar conditions, (3) Control group, (4) Standardization of procedures, (5) Statistical analysis and (6) Other risk of bias. 
During the quality assessment, each parameter for all included study will be evaluated as “low”, “high” or “unclear” risk of bias. Two independent authors will evaluate the included manuscripts (A.F.A.B. and C.O.L). 
Disagreements between authors will be resolved by the intervention of a third author (E.J.N.L.S). If any parameter is considered to be “unclear”, the author will be contacted by electronic message in order to obtain more information.

The quantitative analysis will be carried out on the studies that provide the mean, standard deviation of reduction percentage of AHTD, and the number of specimens per group used. The meta-analysis will be performed using the RevMan software (version 5.2; the Nordic Cochrane Centre, the Cochrane Collaboration, 2012, Copenhagen, Denmark). The heterogeneity among the studies will be tested through the Higgs index.

attributes.title: Evaluating the case for integration
attributes.description: This project compares racially integrated neighborhoods to racially segregated neighborhoods of a similar economic standing on a range of health, education, crime, and social integration outcomes from 2000-2018

q2.value: See the attached pre-analysis plan for my hypotheses.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is an observational study. Because the availability of outcome data depends on the measure, the primary analysis has two components: a cross-sectional analysis for outcomes that only have one time-period of measurement and a longitudinal analysis for outcomes that have at least two time-periods of measurement. Both component analyses will make use of weighted least squares regression (WLS) where the weights are the inverse probability of treatment. This weighting scheme ensures that treatment (racially integrated neighborhoods) and control (racially segregated neighborhoods) groups are balanced on observed confounders.

For more information, see the attached pre-analysis plan.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Most data for this study has already been downloaded, but I have not analyzed any of it. Downloading this data was required to identify which outcomes were available and feasible to use at the neighborhood level. In viewing the data, the only information that I observed were the title of outcome measures and geographic identifiers, not any values of the outcomes themselves.

question.value: This study includes information on the economic standing of all census tracts in MSAs from 2000-2018. It also includes information on a range of outcome measures. The study period is broken into three time-periods: 2000, 2008-2012, and 2014-2018. All of the data, except for one potential variable for exploratory analysis, is publicly available online. I have already downloaded much of this data, but have not begun any analysis yet.  See the attached pre-analysis plan for more information.

q11.value: The sample includes all census tracts located within the 372 metropolitan statistical areas in the U.S. in 2000, 2008-2012, and 2014-2018. The census tract is the unit of analysis. A census tract proxies for a neighborhood and usually includes between 2,500 to 8,000 people.

q12.value: I limit the sample to census tracts located in MSAs primarily to maintain comparability with previous studies that analyze patterns of racial integration over time.

question.value: N/A
Please see attached pre-analysis plan for details on outcome measures, predictors, and covariates.
Please see attached pre-analysis plan for details on outcome measures, predictors, and covariates.

For cross-sectional analyses, I will be using weighted least squares (WLS) multiple regression. For longitudinal analyses, I will use a marginal structural model, which will also include WLS multiple regression. The weights will be the inverse probability of treatment, estimated via covariate balancing propensity scores (CBPS). Please see the Study Design section of the attached pre-analysis plan for further details on methodology.

q18.value: All covariates in the model will be mean-centered. Several covariates and outcome measures will be log transformed. These functional forms are subject to change based on pre-weighting diagnostics that I will carry out (bivariate plots and crosstabs). Please see the Data and Study Design sections of the attached pre-analysis plan for further details.

q19.value: I will use two-sided hypothesis tests with an alpha value of 0.05 for significance. I will adjust p values for the multiple tests that I am running using the Benjamini–Hochberg procedure. I will estimate standard errors via bootstrapping.

q20.value: An outlier that is clearly the result of incorrectly entered or recorded data (if any) will be dropped from the sample and detailed in the analysis. Additionally, I will be conducting regression diagnostic checks to analyze residuals and determine if outliers are affecting the results. If there is an outlier that seems to be driving significant associations, I will rerun the analysis without it and observe how the results change. Significant associations due to an outlier will not be reported.

q21.value: As for missing values, if they affect less than five percent of the overall sample and rates of missingness do not differ by more than 5 percentage points across treatment and control status for any variable, then they will be dropped from the weighting procedure and thus, not be included in the regression analyses (listwise deletion). Otherwise, I will use multiple imputation to correct for this. The default will be 10 iterations, but I may increase the number of iterations depending on whether diagnostics require it.

q22.value: Please see the Exploratory analyses section of the attached pre-analysis plan for details.
